across.text: Restricts little person that’s a bit of a jumper?
across.explanation: CHAINSTITCH(i.e. “that’s a bit of a jumper”). When read as CHAINS TITCH, the solution also satisfies “restricts little person”.

across.text: A learner needing a supporter is hugged by maidens saying the wrong thing
across.explanation: MALAPROPISM(i.e. “saying the wrong thing”). Solution is A, L (a recognised abbreviation of “learner”), A, PROP (i.e. “supporter”) and IS all placed between or “hugged by” M and M (recognised abbreviations of a “maiden” over in cricket), like so: M-(A-L-A-PROP-IS)-M.

across.text: Establishing standard old room in local
across.explanation: NORMATIVE(i.e. “establishing standard”). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and RM (ditto “room”) both placed “in” NATIVE (i.e. “local”), like so: N(O-RM)ATIVE.

across.text: No time for speech with men showing fatigue
across.explanation: LANGUOR(i.e. “fatigue”). Solution is LANGUAGE (i.e. “speech”) with the AGE removed (indicated by “no time”) and the remainder followed by OR (i.e. “men”, specifically the Other Ranks of the British Army), like so: LANGU-OR.

across.text: Rows of headless corpses
across.explanation: TIFFS(i.e. “rows”). Solution is STIFFS (i.e. “corpses”) with the initial letter removed (indicated by “headless”). If you were listening carefully around 2pm this afternoon you’d have heard me groan loudly when I finally twigged this one. Like it!

across.text: Soldier and reformer meeting a king
across.explanation: HUSSAR(i.e. “solider”). Solution is Jan HUSS (i.e. “reformer” – no, me neither) followed by A and R (a recognised abbreviation of Rex, Latin for “king”).

across.text: Behavioural science Hoyle got wrong
across.explanation: ETHOLOGY(i.e. “behavioural science”). “Wrong” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of HOYLE GOT.

across.text: Rage, having to eat a dry fish
across.explanation: RAT-TAIL(i.e. “fish” – an ugly bugger too). Solution is RAIL (i.e. “[to] rage”) wrapped around or “eating” A and TT (a recognised abbreviation of teetotal, i.e. “dry”), like so: R(A-TT)AIL.

across.text: In Barbados, say, how you’d get the measure of the enemy?
across.explanation: ATLANTIC STANDARD TIME(i.e. “in Barbados, say”).Don’t know what the setter’s playing at here, nor am I in much of a mood to go hunting high and low across the internet for an explanation. Sorry, peeps.[EDIT: A nod to Steve in the comments, who highlighted that “time is the enemy” – a phrase I’ll admit didn’t spring to mind. Thanks, Steve! – LP]

across.text: Steps to keep the Queen uncontaminated
across.explanation: STERILE(i.e. “uncontaminated”). Solution is STILE (i.e. “steps”) wrapped around or “keeping” ER (i.e. “the Queen”, specifically Elizabeth Regina), like so: ST(ER)ILE.

across.text: Pioneer crossword compiler entertains only third of solvers
across.explanation: SETTLER(i.e. “pioneer”). Solution is SETTER (i.e. “crossword compiler”) wrapped around or “entertaining” L (i.e. “third [letter] of solvers”), like so: SETT(L)ER.

across.text: Research specialist only half way through stories
across.explanation: EXPLORE(i.e. “research”). Solution is EXPERT (i.e. “specialist”) with the last half lopped off (indicated by “only half way through”) and followed by LORE (i.e. “stories”), like so: EXP-LORE.

across.text: Light colour of old city church to the west
across.explanation: ECRU(i.e. “light colour”). Solution is UR (i.e. “old city” – a bit of a favourite of setters) and CE (i.e. “church”, specifically the Church of England) both reversed (indicated by “to the west”, this being an across clue), like so: EC-RU. One gotten through the wordplay.

across.text: Girl’s best friend in a suit?
across.explanation: DIAMONDS. Solution satisfies “girl’s best friend” – referring to the songDiamonds are a Girl’s Best FriendfromGentlemen Prefer Blondes– and “in a suit [of playing cards]”.

across.text: Biblical tribe, possible adherents of a god of wealth, dismissing leader
across.explanation: AMMONITES(i.e. “Biblical tribe”). Solution is MAMMONITES (i.e. “possible adherents of a god of wealth”) with the initial letter removed (indicated by “dismissing leader”). Score one for the Bradford’s here.

across.text: Community travel entangled after reversing set of instructions
across.explanation: DECALOGUE, relating to the Ten Commandments in The Bible (i.e. “set of instructions”). Solution is EU (i.e. “community”, specifically the European Union) followed by GO (i.e. “travel”) and LACED (i.e. “entangled”) all “reversed”, like so: DECAL-OG-UE. Got the DECAL bit but had to brute force Chambers for the rest.

across.text: Papa dislikes aspects of birthday celebrations
across.explanation: PRESENTS(i.e. “aspects of birthday celebrations”). Solution is P (i.e. “Papa” in the phonetic alphabet) followed by RESENTS (i.e. “dislikes”).

across.text: A guerrilla gets hurt
across.explanation: ACHE(i.e. “hurt”). Solution is A followed by CHE Guevara (i.e. “guerrilla”).

across.text: Uses swearword when coming across cat
across.explanation: CUSTOMS(i.e. “uses”). Solution is CUSS (i.e.” swearword”) wrapped around or “coming across” TOM (i.e. “cat”), like so: CUS(TOM)S.

across.text: Walked, bumping into Peg in the tube
across.explanation: TETRODE(i.e. a kind of valve or vacuum “tube”). Solution is TROD (i.e. “walked”) placed or “bumped into” TEE (i.e. “peg” – ignore the misleading capitalisation), like so: TE(TROD)E. Another nod to my Bradford’s.

across.text: Onion in English allotment
across.explanation: SHALLOT(i.e. “onion”). “In” indicates the solution is hidden in the clue, like so: ENGLI(SH ALLOT)MENT.

across.text: Like good guys supporting the LA baseball team?
across.explanation: ON THE SIDE OF THE ANGELS. Solution satisfies “like good guys” and “supporting the LA baseball team”, referring to the Los Angeles Angels. Use of “the” in the clue might be stretching it a bit for any Dodgers fans out there…(puts away Cody Bellinger Dodgers shirt).

across.text: Something frightening, British, and not half unattractive to put up with
across.explanation: BUGBEAR(i.e. “something frightening”). Solution is B (a recognised abbreviation of “British”) followed by UGLY (i.e. “unattractive”) with the last half removed (indicated by “not half”) and then BEAR (i.e. “to put up with”), like so: B-UG-BEAR.

across.text: Car well able to convey limited number, offering independence
across.explanation: AUTONOMY(i.e. “independence”). Solution is AUTO (i.e. “car”) and MY (i.e. “well”, both expressions of astonishment) wrapped around or “conveying” ONE (i.e. “number”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “limited”), like so: AUT(ON)O-MY. You could also argue “limited number” means a recognised abbreviation of “number”, which would make the solution AUTO-(NO)-MY. I prefer the former explanation.

across.text: Fashionable philosopher put to rest?
across.explanation: INHUME(i.e. “put to rest”). Solution is IN (i.e. “fashionable”) followed by David HUME (i.e. “philosopher”). A nod to Monty Python’sPhilosophers Songfor that one.

across.text: Turmoil when duke meets a divine being in India
across.explanation: DRAMA(i.e. “turmoil”). Solution is D (a recognised abbreviation of “duke”) followed by RAMA (i.e. “divine being in India”).

across.text: What get hot and black: ships carrying fuel
across.explanation: BOILERS(i.e. “what get hot”). Solution is B (a recognised abbreviation of “black” used in chess) followed by OILERS (i.e. “ships carrying fuel”).

across.text: Arguing about a boy, one no good
across.explanation: REASONING(i.e. “arguing”). Solution is RE (i.e. “about” – think email replies) followed by A, then SON (i.e. “boy”), then I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”), then N (a recognised abbreviation of “no”) and G (ditto “good”), like so: RE-A-SON-I-N-G.

across.text: What is evident in weighty section of song
across.explanation: MIDDLE EIGHT(i.e. “section of song”). “What is evident in weighty” refers to how EIGHT forms the MIDDLE of the word “weighty”.

across.text: Heeding Lent, possibly, being wise?
across.explanation: ENLIGHTENED(i.e. “being wise”). “Possibly” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of HEEDING LENT.

down.text: Study church with a shell-like structure
down.explanation: CONCHA(i.e. “shell-like structure”). Solution is CON (i.e. an archaic word for “study” that setters like to use in their clues) followed by CH (a recognised abbreviation of “church”) and A. One gotten through the wordplay and a quick check in Chambers, if I’m honest.

down.text: Where naughty children run riskily in slum area
down.explanation: ACROSS THE TRACKS. Solution satisfies “where naughty children run riskily” and “in slum area”.

down.text: A peasant organised home to be very clean and tidy
down.explanation: NEAT AS A PIN(i.e. “very clean and tidy”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “organised”) of A PEASANT followed by IN (i.e. “[at] home”), like so: NEATASAP-IN.

down.text: Holiday mishap
down.explanation: TRIP. Solution satisfies “holiday” and “mishap”.

down.text: Don’t move into these inadequate rural areas
down.explanation: THE STICKS(i.e. “rural areas”). Solution is STICK (i.e. “don’t move”) placed into THESEonce the last letter has been removed (indicated by “inadequate”), like so: THE(STICK)S.

down.text: Assist goddess with petulant expression
down.explanation: HELP OUT(i.e. “assist”). Solution is HEL (i.e. Norse “goddess” of death) followed by POUT (i.e. “petulant expression”).

down.text: Rainy season’s coming before long in Mediterranean country? No thanks!
down.explanation: MONSOONAL(i.e. “rainy season”). Solution is ON SOON (i.e. “coming before long”) placed in MALTA (i.e. “Mediterranean country”) once the TA has been removed (indicated by “No thanks!”), like so: M(ON-SOON)AL.

down.text: Envy destroying three leading characters? That’s very bad
down.explanation: LOUSY(i.e. “that’s very bad”). Solution is JEALOUSY (i.e. “envy”) with the first three letters removed (indicated by “destroying three leading characters”).

down.text: Some game requiring quiet skill, game without leader
down.explanation: PARTRIDGE(i.e. “some game [bird]”). Solution is P (a recognised abbreviation of piano, i.e. “quiet” in music lingo) followed by ART (i.e. “skill”) and BRIDGE (i.e. “game”) once its initial letter has been removed (indicated by “without leader”), like so: P-ART-RIDGE.

down.text: Surpassing dodgy dealers, first to last? Excellent!
down.explanation: OUTSTRIPPING(i.e. “surpassing”). Solution is TOUTS (i.e. “dodgy dealers”) with the first letter placed at the end (indicated by “first to last”). This is then followed by RIPPING (i.e. “excellent”), like so: OUTST-RIPPING.

down.text: Extend home and start to fall behind schedule
down.explanation: INFLATE(i.e. “extend”). Solution is IN (i.e. “[at] home”) followed by F (i.e. “start to fall”, i.e. the first letter of “fall”) and LATE (i.e. “behind schedule”).

down.text: Menu’s beginning with a cold dish, mostly spicy stuff
down.explanation: MASALA(i.e. “spicy stuff”). Solution is M (i.e. “menu’s beginning”, i.e. the first letter of “menu”) followed by A and SALAD (i.e. “cold dish”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “mostly”), like so: M-A-SALA.

down.text: Male talking thus may be grumbling
down.explanation: UTTERING. Solution is M (a recognised abbreviation of “male”) which, when placed before the solution, UTTERING, gets you M-UTTERING (i.e. “grumbling”).

down.text: Floridly rhetorical poet given honour, not the first
down.explanation: AUREATE(i.e. “floridly rhetorical”). Solution is LAUREATE (i.e. “poet given honour”) with the initial letter removed (indicated by “not the first”).

down.text: Man joining the girl in risky enterprise that may help the rest
down.explanation: BEDSHEET(i.e. “that may help the rest” – “rest” as in sleep). Solution is ED (i.e. “man”, i.e. a shortened form of Edward) and SHE (i.e. “the girl”) placed “in” BET (i.e. “risky venture”), like so: B(ED-SHE)ET.

down.text: Bird, needing drink, had to go inside
down.explanation: SHELDUCK(i.e. “bird”). Solution is SUCK (i.e. “drink”) wrapped around or having “inside” HELD (i.e.” had”), like so: S(HELD)UCK.

down.text: Not, we may deduce, travelling quickly
down.explanation: TON-UP(i.e. “travelling quickly”, i.e. over 100mph). “We may deduce” indicates the solution is itself a cryptic clue, describing “not”, i.e. the word “ton” in reverse (indicated by “up” – this being a down clue).

down.text: Political lion somehow traps you and me – it’s not what is seems
down.explanation: OPTICAL ILLUSION(i.e. “it’s not what it seems”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “somehow”) of POLITICAL LION wrapped around or “trapping” US (i.e. “you and me”), like so: OPTICALILL(US)ION.

down.text: Prominent men wanting girl to undress (not showing bottom though)
down.explanation: MAESTRI(i.e. “prominent men”, plural of maestro). Solution is MAE STRIP (i.e. “girl to undress”) with the last letter of STRIP removed (indicated by “not showing bottom though”), like so: MAE-STRI.

down.text: Old-fashioned office worker, good person one upset
down.explanation: STENO(i.e. “old-fashioned office worker”, specifically an abbreviated form of stenographer). Solution is ST (i.e. “good person”, i.e. a recognised abbreviation of “saint”) followed by an anagram (indicated by “upset”) of ONE, like so: ST-ENO.

down.text: Wasn’t Emu naughty bird?
down.explanation: MUTE SWAN(i.e. “bird”). “Naughty” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of WASN’T EMU. Nicely worked.

down.text: Secret observer won’t half yell when rumbled
down.explanation: FLY ON THE WALL(i.e. “secret observer”). “When rumbled” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of WON’T HALF YELL.

down.text: Displaying message opposing capital punishment?
down.explanation: HANGING OUT. Solution satisfies “displaying” – we’ve all been there, love – and “message opposing capital punishment”.

down.text: Always kept in outhouse, as car needs to be
down.explanation: STEERABLE(i.e. “as car needs to be”). Solution is E’ER (poetic form of ever, i.e. “always”) placed or “kept in” STABLE (i.e. “outhouse”), like so: ST(E’ER)ABLE.

down.text: Discussion of tricky matter with Treebeard?
down.explanation: TREATMENT(i.e. “discussion”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “tricky”) of MATTER followed by ENT (i.e. “Treebeard” – one for Tolkien fans, Ents were living trees, one of whom was called Treebeard), like so: TREATM-ENT.

down.text: Terrible male here should keep quiet, being “here today, gone tomorrow”
down.explanation: EPHEMERAL(i.e. “here today, gone tomorrow”). Solution is an anagram (indicate by “terrible”) of MALE HERE wrapped around or “keeping” P (a recognised abbreviation of piano, i.e. “quiet” in music lingo), like so: E(P)HEMERAL.

down.text: Vigilant when a ground can get out of control
down.explanation: ON GUARD(i.e. “vigilant”). “Can get out of control” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of A GROUND.

down.text: Expression of disgust about head’s artifice
down.explanation: FINESSE(i.e. “artifice”). Solution is FIE (i.e. “expression of disgust”) wrapped “about” NESS (i.e. “head”, as in a geographical feature), like so: FI(NESS)E.

down.text: This writer’s about to wait in the same location
down.explanation: IBIDEM(i.e. Latin for “in the same location” – if you ever see “ibid” in a footnote of some text, it’s a way of not having to repeat references to the same source all the time). Solution is I’M (i.e. “this writer’s”, i.e. a contraction of “this writer is”, or “I am” taken from the point of view of the setter) wrapped “about” BIDE (i.e. “to wait”), like so: I(BIDE)’M. Nicely done.

down.text: “Deeply” powerful male?
down.explanation: SEA GOD(i.e. “powerful male”). The “deeply” bit qualifies this particular god to be one from the seas.

down.text: Imitating a sort of sound
down.explanation: APING(i.e. “imitating”). When written as A PING the solution also satisfies “a sort of sound”.

down.text: Made a call, cutting row short
down.explanation: RANG(i.e. “made a call”). Solution is RANGE (i.e. “row”) with the last letter removed (indicated by “cutting…short”).
